I have found that a lot of the ones I take short cuts with and don't bother making stories for I end up having to relearn and don't stick with me very well. I did a test once where I tried to learn 20 new words using mnemonics and 20 without. I remembered way way more of the mnemonic ones. In that sense spending a minute to make a word stick is much more time efficient.

My friend (in the vid) showed me this method a while ago and I don't know how people learn vocab without it. It's made a big difference to my learning, and he has just published this vid about it, with part 2 coming, so I thought I'd share it.
The actual method is in the last third of the vid if you wanna skip right to it, but the whole vid is interesting I think.

I agree about not being an elitist, but I don't see why having a wide taste would be linked to maturity. Some people are just into particular types of music. For example, if Jazz music is your thing and you don't have that same passion for other genres, I would struggle to call that immature taste. You just have a genre that speaks to you more than others do.
On the flip side, I would suggest that understanding that all taste is inherently subjective, and not objective, is a more mature approach.

Yes but using "literally" to intensify a statement which is figurative is different from using the word figurative. Even if what I am saying is figurative. Even if we accept that it is the incorrect use of the word "literally" (which I don't), we certainly DON'T mean "figuratively".

No one uses "literally" when they mean "figuratively". Saying "literally" intensifies the sentiment, whereas "figuratively" clarifies that you are not being literal, essentially doing the opposite. Hate this shit.

Where is a good place to find these kinds of materials for a one off payment for unlimited use, or even an annual subscription. I am willing to pay for the material, however as the youtube channel will be completely not for profit, I can't afford to shell out for licenses every video.
If anyone has any tips or links that could help me, that would be great. Thanks for your help.

WRITING.TEXT:
If I die in 50 years time or so, why does what happens in hundreds or thousands of years time make any difference to me at all?
I got as much pleasure as I could from the world, and passed on the opportunity to some other people if that's what I wanted to do. Whether it lasts forever is completely irrelevant.
The point is to create happiness in ourselves and others.

The fact that you are posting this suggests that you have doubts about how you are living. The risk you are running is that as you age these doubts will develop into regrets.
If you are honestly and truly happy with yourself and believe you will continue to be over the coming decades, there is nothing that needs to be changed. As long as you are not trying to fool yourself out of fear of failure. There is a lot of joy to be found in the world. You only get one go.

Awesome reply, I agree with a lot of what you said. A large part of why I want to get over my cheese hatred is to experience these cuisines they way they're meant to be. I love asian food and when I go there I want to try all the food the way they locals eat it. Luckily with almost all asia food I don't need to worry about cheese at all. If I go to Mexico or somewhere, I don't want to be the guy saying "This, but without cheese please"

Good comment. I think there's something in the "this is how it's supposed to taste" thing. A large part of it is mindset. It's interesting you mentioned cilantro, I'm the only person in my family that likes it, I can't get enough.

WRITING.TITLE: Can you train yourself to start liking foods you don't like?
WRITING.TEXT:
I love food and I love cooking. I consider myself to be fairly open minded with food and I love trying new food, especially different cuisines when travelling. However I find it very frustrating when there is food that I "don't like".
For me cheese is the worst one. It's annoying because it's in so many different dishes, and everyone seems to love it except for me.
When I was a kid I wouldn't eat any cheese at all. Now I can eat mozzarella and Halloumi, which are probably the least cheesy cheeses. I can't even eat a bit of mild cheddar.
I don't expect to be eating strong blue cheeses anytime soon, but is there a way to train yourself to some extent to enjoy a food that you previously didn't like? Or do I have to just accept that I'll never enjoy cheese?
Album is sounding awesome so far
Love the colours

Not a strawman. I've taken exactly what you said.
It depends what you mean by "unable to function mentally". Most humans who are mentally handicapped in some way are still fully conscious, still feel emotion the same way as everyone else, still are self aware in a way that most animals aren't.

"Animals are Living and thus Innately valuable"
Plants are also living. So are bacteria.
I think a better system is to not act like all living things are equal, but to examine to what kind of rights are deserving of what kind of animals.
I believe that Humans deserve more rights than animals because we have a much higher level of understanding and awareness, and higher capacity for emotional suffering.
In the same way, I believe that Chimpanzees also deserve a fair amount of rights because they are very intelligent, social creatures, that have emotions. I think most people would agree that it is not ethical to farm chimpanzees for this reason.
Chickens also deserve rights, of course, they should not have to suffer severe pain and stress, but they essentially do not have the same level of understanding, emotion and intelligence than humans or chimpanzees.
Ants have no real emotional capacity and we therefore do not lose much sleep if we accidentally step on one.
Animals can be placed on a scale from the most intelligent and emotional at the top to the least at the bottom. Doesn't it make more sense to give rights based on where an animal falls on this scale rather than equal rights to all?

But also remember that Facebook can be a pretty important tool for staying in touch with people, especially if you're not seeing people regularly. It's about using the positive aspects of it and not getting hung up with how you're portraying your life.

I relate to what you're saying. You have to get over your anxieties and accept every invitation you get, otherwise it will be a spiral that just gets worse. I wouldn't worry about the facebook thing. I know plenty of people that live life to the absolute fullest and have empty facebook profiles.

I don't think that link really says that breasts are not biologically sexual, or that it's entirely a modern western thing.
I agree that there are many cultures that have no problem with bare breasts. There are also come cultures that are fine with complete nudity, it doesn't mean that genitals are not sexual in their culture.
The sexualisation of breasts varies from place to place, as it is a mixture of culture and biology. In the modern west breasts are probably more sexualised than anywhere else. That is our culture, I agree.
So what point are you making, that we should break down the "cultural" side, and ignore the biological side. Why try and change such a prevalent cultural feeling for such a relatively minor gain. There are also positive aspects to the sexualisation of breasts remember.
Also, an interesting read: https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-human-beast/201305/sexual-wiring-womens-breasts
I said from the start that it's a combination of culture and biology. No I don't buy that it's entirely a modern western culture thing.

WRITING.TITLE: Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon), Vietnam [5471x3074][OC]

WRITING.TEXT:
I understand that breasts aren't genitals, but they are sexual organs, and not just because some men ages ago decided that we can shame women with them. Men's chests are not sexual organs in the same way, and not just because we're used to seeing them more.
Women's bodies are different from men's bodies. Is it double standards that women don't have urinals in their bathrooms? No, because they have different bodies. I understand that people want to argue that women's breasts aren't sexual organs, but I assure you that men don't feel the way they do about them just because they're not used to seeing them.
Edit: Also I want to state that I'm not arguing for or against a woman's right to go topless in public. I just think there is no hypocrisy or double standards at play.

Ok, so you're saying that if hygiene wasn't an issue, then public nudity of ALL kinds should be absolutely fine. That's a perfectly fine stance to have, but it's one I think you have to accept. Although it may be your argument against public nudity, there any many people who consider it inappropriate for reasons aside from hygiene.
The reason I'm pressing this point is that you seem to imply that people single out female breasts, when they don't, because they feel the same about genitals of both genders, and not for hygiene reasons. My point is, there is no hypocrisy or double standards at play.

You've sidestepped the argument by bringing in hygiene. There are many situations where hygiene isn't really an issue, for example, the beach.
Your second argument can also be applied to full nudity. I don't think you have a serious argument unless you can address this issue.
I love Vietnamese scarecrows. I took this pic last year in Can Tho: http://i.imgur.com/tQ7WrZQ.jpg

Do you think that people, both men and women, should be allowed to go fully nude in public? If not, then why not? It seems like you have selected toplessness because you see it as "unfair" that men get to go topless and women don't. The thing is, female breasts are much more of a sexual organ than the male chest. That's probably a mix of culture and biology, but that's not changing any time soon.
Even if you changed the laws (I don't know what they are) about women going topless in public, how do you expect to change how men "feel" about breasts. What point are you actually arguing? Are you just stating that it's not fair? Because it's also not fair that women have to deal with periods every month, or experience pain in childbirth. These things aren't decided by men, they're the way things are.
I would keep the aspect ratio and crop from just left of the crossing, not cropping anything from the right or bottom.

ah, ok, appreciated.
I agree with you but I'm not the OP

In most cases, I don't consider lying about something rape. That doesn't mean it's ok, obviously. I don't think it is useful to stretch the definition of rape to things like saying you don't have a girlfriend to someone. I'm sure there are exceptions and extreme situations.
Keeping perspective, and not vocalising our problems are two completely different things.

Well that's a semantic argument, but if someone claimed that they had been raped, and it later turned out that what they meant was "he lied about his age", I would find that a pretty disrespectful use of the word "rape".

Firstly, do you not think it's a good thing to try to speak out against the injustices in the world, to help change the world for the better, however slight that change may be in the grand scheme of things. For example, should gay people have not said anything about the prejudice that they faced? Change doesn't happen if nobody vocalises the problems and injustices. That goes from important things like racial prejudice, to more insignificant things like a workplace environment being demotivating.
Secondly, people are people, they need to express how they feel. Everyone has problems. It gets you through life to share them. I'll share with friends or a partner problems as big as someone i care about dying to as small as missing a train, and they will to me in return. It helps us through life. It doesn't mean that we don't realise that many people have it much worse off than us.

I believe that anything that you hide from your partner where they would not consent to sex with you if they were informed of it is considered Rape by Deception.
This is a problem, because you don't know what every person's boundaries are. Some people wouldn't sleep with someone if they'd slept over a certain number of people. It's not rape to not disclose that information beforehand. So what's the difference?
You can say that there are many people would be MORE upset by finding out a partner's birth gender is different than they thought. That still doesn't make it rape, whether it's ethical or not.
You haven't provided a reason why birth gender is somehow different to religion, race, number of partners, sexuality, favourite football team, etc etc.
What about it? I didn't say he shouldn't have been interrupted. I just said it would have been embarrassing for him.
My fav Coen movie.

To the people claiming they don't get why it's cringey, it's because a man is being told off in the middle of doing his job on live tv, which is probably quite embarrassing for him. Something can be cringey and funny at the same time. I don't know why there are always comments saying "this isn't cringe".

The reason I'm focusing on that definition is because you've defined "God" but then are using that definition to make claims about a different definition of God.
I accept that you can define God in the way that are you (albeit unhelpfully), but you can't use that to make any logical claims about religion or belief systems.
I'm not just disputing your premise, I'm also disputing your conclusion. If God is all, I believe that many belief systems are not true. You say that if God is all, then the bible is the word of God. Which definition of God are you using, your definition or the Bible's very different definition. The Bible claims it is the word of the Christian God. It doesn't claim it's the word of your God definition.

This is what it looks like you have said to me:
"If x is true, then people that say x isn't true are wrong"
But x isn't true.
If cats are teapots then you can make tea with cats. But cats aren't teapots. So what's your point?

it wouldn't matter unless I was talking to another person (because then they don't know what I'm talking about)
You are talking to other people and I have no idea what you are talking about because you are taking a word and using it in a way that doesn't make sense.
So let's call it "goopurt".
The major world religions don't really have anything to say about goopurt, they make claims about various Gods. When they make claims that are true, that is goopurt, as goopurt is everything. If they make claims that are false, for example about the nature of God, that is goopurt too. Because goopurt is everything. Just because something is goopurt doesn't make it true.

God has a specific meaning, which it seems like you have changed without justifying why.
You can't just say "God is everything". What does that actually mean? By most definitions, God is a personal and powerful creator, of some sort.
What evidence do you have that God is everything?

You seem stuck on the point that being black makes you "more likely to be prone to crime".
I want to take the analogy that /u/wonkay gave and explore it.
Imagine that 70% of American boys had their legs operated (for whatever reason) on to make them significantly weaker at running fast.
Now the statistics will say that American men are bad at running.
Now do you think it's reasonable to say to an American man who has not had that operation as a child, that he is more likely to be bad at running because he is an American man.
If he explains to you that he hasn't had the operation as a child and that he is a very fast runner, will you tell him that the statistics don't lie and the "reasons" behind them don't matter?
The reason why racism is bad is that we should judge people as individuals, not based on statistics.
Absolutely love this image.

Firstly, I don't think you've made any argument as to why future art will not be as good as last art. We've had thousands of years of art. You've picked a couple of important artists and claimed that nothing will top it. Why won't they? In the hundreds or thousands of years to come, why is it unlikely for someone to make art as great as the last greats.
Secondly, art isn't just some old relic to be judged by its historical impact. Art is about communicating ideas, creating passion and excitement amongst people, creating something that people relate to, something relevant to the audience of today.
Nothing against the Mona Lisa but I'm more excited to hear the new Radiohead album.
That should be interesting for meatballs.

Your post makes you seem very concerned about how people will judge you and your family. Your relationship with your children and your responsibility to support them is more important than what your bigoted neighbours will say about you. If you are in an area where being gay is difficult, well that means that your children require MORE support from you, not LESS.
Also if you are concerned about how people will view you, as time goes on, more and more people are viewing the non-support of gay people to be unacceptable.
Amazing

Success in terms of career and money doesn't equal happiness. I know many people don't believe that, but it really is only part of the equation.
Lack of empathy may well lead you to faster financial or career success in many situations, but that is not really what you are after. What you really want is happiness.
I think people that care about other people and have people care about them are the happiest people. There are plenty of "successful" people that are not happy.
While success and empathy both contribute to a person's happiness, I think that empathy has a bigger impact. The joys of material possessions wear off, regardless how much you have. What's the point of having success if you lack the empathy to enjoy it and share it with others.

WRITING.TITLE: Where did you get (/would you get) video for your website?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm trying to market my freelance videography services to small businesses. If you have a video on your website, who made it and where did you find them?
If you wanted to have a video made, where would be the first places you would search? Obviously for many people Google would be the first port of call, but I'm trying to figure out other ways to get hold of businesses that might be interested in my services. Thanks for any help or insight you can give me.

A child aged 4 is going to have an easier time learning a language in a new country than someone age 24. That doesn't mean 4 year olds are more intelligent than adults. It's easier to acquire new skills at a younger age, this is the same for every generation.

Great reply thanks. The videos I do would be things like product demos, brand videos, talking heads, shots of the actual business, so I'm not really competing with what people can do with stock elements in that sense. Perhaps a way around that would be the developer approaches the client about potential videos after the website has been set up, or something like that.
Thanks for the response, I'm still obviously just figuring things out atm.

WRITING.TITLE: Advice needed: Videographer looking to build relationships with local web developers
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm a freelance videographer (Surrey, UK), who wants to build some relationships with local web designers and developers in the New Year. I would really appreciate it if anyone could give me some advice regarding my plan.
What I want to do is have web developers offer their clients video services, and then refer them to me to do the work. My rate would be around 450 depending on the project. The web developer could mark up the price to what they feel is appropriate, say 600. They can be as involved or not involved as they like in the process.
I get more business my way, the web developer gets money for very little extra work, the client gets a service they need. No one stands to lose very much from the deal.
From a web developer perspective, what are the pros and cons of the deal for you? Do you think it is a deal that many people would go for? What would be the best way to approach them? I am not naturally a great business thinker, so any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thanks
Thought this said "have actual sting play" and couldn't figure out the connection.

The analogy doesn't work in any way because you're comparing something that doesn't matter o something that does matter. If someone agrees to sign a petition without asking what your intention is then they don't care about your intention. If someone sleeps with you without it asking what your intention is then they may well still care about your intention. Yes there is some responsibility in them to find out what your intention is but that still doesn't make it right on your part. I don't think it makes you morally appalling, I just think it makes you a creep.

The petition analogy really doesn't work in my opinion, because a petition is always FOR something. But if you want to go down that route, I would suggest a more fitting analogy would be if you were collection signatures from people and using them for something you know they wouldn't agree with, eg a racist organisation, or something like that. I'm sure you can charm them out of a signature without telling them what it's for, but is it ethical to use those signatures for an organisation you know they would disagree with?

Presumably you would not tell anyone that you are with about your goal beforehand. How many of those people do you think would have turned you down if they knew about your goal of 100 people? I think this is where the problem lies. I would think about what your goal really is. Is it to experience a good time with a lot of people? Maybe then it is best to focus on the people and the experiences rather than on the numbers.

It means that different people like different things? You seem to be the one making the straw man. I haven't said or implied that any of it doesn't have a place in metal or that people shouldn't like it or that other people don't relate to it. It's great that people love these genres of metal and embrace the culture and the aesthetic, I would never argue otherwise. I am saying that I am glad that there has been a shift in recent years towards things that I personally relate to better.

I'm not talking about the average fan, I'm talking about the images and styles that are associated with metal. I don't think I've ever seen anyone wearing corpse paint in my life, but it's and image that is associated with black metal. Type in "black metal" into google images and all the images are black and white, corpse paint and illegible band names. I personally don't mind that aesthetic, but my only point is, I am happy that it is becoming more common to take the sounds that I like from these more extreme genres of metal, and combining them with an aesthetic that I personally relate to more.

Nothing against anyone who dresses like this (or any way) but long hair, studs, tattoos, leather, huge baggy black t-shirts, make-up, chains, skulls, corpse paint etc isn't really my thing. I like some of it, but a lot of it isn't really what I'm into and it's so common in metal. I do sometimes wish there was a bit more diversity in visual style in metal. Frankly I do quite like that deafheaven have less of that stuff in their image. Not that any of it is really a big deal, when it comes down to it, if the music is good, it's good.
I've loved metal for years, but I'm very glad that it's becoming more common to see bands wearing more "normal" clothes, because I've always hated metal fashion.
YEAHHHH, takes me back!

To put it bluntly, people enjoy eating in restaurants. You might as well say that theatre, sport, bars, cinemas and amusement parks are useless to society. People enjoy them, they are (mostly) a luxury that people use to treat themselves.
If you enjoy food a lot, (I do), then eating at a restaurant is an opportunity to eat food that you cannot cook yourself, due to insufficient skill, patience or equipment, and socialise whilst doing it.
Also when you cook yourself, it is easy to get into habits of using the same techniques and ingredients. Eating out offers inspiration and variety.

Most of the time, in my experience, I have found that people assume the "pretentious douchebag" part just based on their interests or fashion. How many times have you read on reddit "pretentious douchebag" just based on a photo of someone with facial hair and a record player or something like that. No one knows if that person is pretentious or not, they just have a beard and like vinyl records, or old films or foreign food.
There are pretentious douchebags amongst people who like mainstream stuff too. Many of them call people hipseters for liking alternative stuff.

I realise that this is a somewhat lazy post by me, but this Stephen Fry video really nicely articulates the problem with the using the sense of wonder at nature as evidence for a god.

I would say that how hard working you are refers to your natural and acquired potential and how hard you work is what you actually do with it.
Unless your view is all pride is pointless regardless of everything. You can say that there's no free will, life is deterministic and we're just a bunch of atoms bouncing around, but what's the point? Why would you want to deny yourself and others a positive emotion that you have earned through hard work. Regardless of circumstances and genes, hard work is still hard. Reward yourself with pride over your successes and use that list for pride to help you succeed in life.
I would say there is a difference in how "hard working" you are and how hard you work. It's more difficult for a naturally lazy person to put the work in but that doesn't mean they can't

Let's take the best athletes in the world in their respective fields as an example. They are superior partly because of their genes, partly because of the circumstances of their birth and upbringing, and **partly because of all the hard work they have put in**. I don't think there are many (any?) athletes who have reached the top without extreme amounts of hard work and self discipline.

Every place is a place with spoilers unless you warn me first, that's the whole point.

Right, but not every forum is labelled "the breaking bad discussion forum". Don't put spoilers in titles, don't post them in threads that are not about that specific thing, unless you warn people first. If spoiler tags are a hassle, that's a problem with the specific forum or sub that you're talking about. It doesn't mean ignore common curtesy.

Well I agree the method of HOW you avoid spoilers is up for debate. Endless hoops to jump through and tags and rules are frustrating for most people I would think. Those are two different questions, should we respect spoilers and how should we do it. The more hassle free the system is the better I think. It just needs to be one word, it takes 1 second.
As for proving that it's worth it, I mean, what do you want? Obviously I can't prove it I can only reason with you. The excitement that I got from watching breaking bad unspoilt was extremely intense for me and many other people. I enjoyed that show so much and I would have genuinely been very unset if certain plot points had been spoilt. There is a middle ground to be had here. If you put the word *spoilers* on a thread that you start, I won't click on it. If I go in and have it spoilt, then that's on me. However it is reasonable to not expect to see unwarned spoilers on my Facebook feed for example.
Im willing to do what is necessary to avoid spoilers that I care about, but I should not have to have them thrust upon me with no warning at all.

You're acting like it takes hours of your time to protect people against spoilers. It literally only takes one word at the beginning of a post. I really really hate it when people don't respect that people don't want to have things spoilt. I much prefer watching something when I don't know what is going to happen.
The pleasure that people get from watching a show or film unspoilt far far outweighs the one second it takes to write *spoilers*.
Coke. Pepsi tastes more artificial and chemically to me.

I'm a very quiet person, but I only find silences awkward when I can tell the other person is uncomfortable with the silence. What I would suggest is when there is a silence in a conversation, make a judgement as to whether the other person seems uncomfortable. If they do, then I think it will probably always be a bit awkward, but if they don't, then there is no reason for you to feel awkward or uncomfortable. If you practise not worrying about filling every silence then they will probably become more comfortable.

For me personally, I worked a job I didn't care about for a few years, with which I funded my hobbies, my travels, and my social life. I have now just got a full time job doing my hobby (music videography). I realise that many people are not as fortunate as me though, and do not get the opportunity to do the thing they care about for a living.
Can you give me an example of what you mean when you say that someone should "do what they like to do" instead of working? How would I go and film a band if I couldn't afford a camera. How would I film a band if I couldn't afford food or a train ticket to the venue?

I have no idea what you mean. So if what I want to do is go to the pub and drink beer, then I should do that? How will I keep my family out of poverty by doing that and how is that sustainable. Also in what way is that a fulfilling life?

Do you think a man with a family will feel fulfilled while failing at some career that he "loves", while his family live in poverty. What if this man loves his family and what he wants most in life is to see them happy and live to see his children grow up? What if he can't afford rent? What if he wants to take his family on a holiday to a place they've always wanted to go? Is it not possible that a job that he doesn't love will result in a net gain in happiness for himself and his family? He might find that more fulfilling than some job than doing something that doesn't pay, doesn't provide safety, security, a nice place to live.
Great concept. For me the mushroom is a bit too bright and the face is a bit too dark. Perhaps if you bring down the highlights and push up the shadows a tiny bit?
I think something like the LOTR extended editions are for if you're already a fan. For me, the last thing I needed LOTR to be is longer.

In theory the directors cut is a version of the film approved by the director which may be closer to their own vision. They're often longer than the theatrical cut, however they're not always better. Also, sometimes it's just a marketing tool. There is a director's cut of Alien, however Ridley Scott has said that the original theatrical cut is the "real" directors cut, and the one he prefers.
Personally I watch the theatrical cut of a film, unless I have it on good authority that a different version is notably superior.

Kanye is certainly not a technical rapper compared to many, however his music is strongly driven by sounds and ideas, rather than sheer rhyming. My personal favourite song of his is Blame Game, if you want a specific recommendation. His lyrics can be extremely thoughtful and emotive and his production is incredible. It is easily understandable to me why so many do not like Kanye (his personality for one), but talentless is certainly not the word.

WRITING.TEXT: If you don't think that is relevant then I don't understand your view at all. It seems obvious to me that a person can make good arguments for a position that I don't agree with. If you agree with my points then what part of your view am I misunderstanding?

Imagine conclusions such as "we should raise taxes in this area by X amount", "behaviour X is morally wrong", "we should restrict the use of substance x". Do you not think there could be valid arguments both for and against these claims. Just because I hold a certain position doesn't mean that all arguments against my position are invalid. Perhaps the argument for my position simply outweigh the arguments against my position. Perhaps if I hear more arguments against my position the "against" will start to outweigh the "for" and I will change my mind.

That is really nitpicking though as this is a critique forum. I love the photo.

Yes but you can't just magic everything better. You can't make prisons better and then just make the rest of life better to make up for it. You might as well say let's give everyone in the world a mansion to live in. It's simply not fair to make prison a more comfortable option than hard working people.

You're saying that homeless people (people with some of the most difficult lives) commonly commit crimes so that they can improve their life, but you're suggesting that we raise the living standards of prison to such an extent that many many more people would have the option to improve their life by committing a crime. Don't you think that it would be fairer to make the legal options more attractive than the illegal ones?

1. Considering that there are many people working very hard to make an honest living, many in very difficult conditions, do you think it is fair that someone who commits a violent crime is fast-tracked to a better life than these hard working people. 2. For many people with difficult lives this will make committing a crime of personal gain a win-win situation. Either you get away with the crime and improve your life, or you go to prison and improve your life. Do you not see a problem with this?

I don't think The Babadook deserves to be lumped in with those other ones you mentioned. I think it's a much more thoughtful movie than that. Have you seen El Orfanato? It's not very recent (2007?) but one of the best modern horror films in my opinion.

Louis CK has an interesting outlook on younger people who think they can do whatever they want while they're young and then they'll just explode at 40: "you don't die you idiot, you just have a shitty second half".
It is impossible to live life "perfectly" in terms of health. However if you live a very unhealthy first half, you are more likely to have a much more difficult second half. Health is a sliding scale, not a yes/no decision to make. Think about the future whilst not giving up everything you love.

It was my understanding that most scientists did believe that life on this planet did arise from non living material, so I think your premise is flawed. But even so, how did the extraterrestrial life arise? At some point, life has to either arise from non living material, or be created by a "creator" (which begs the question how did the creator come to be).

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. The one that started them all! When I watched it as a kid in the cinema as a rerelease in the early 90s I thought it was a brand new film. Wasn't til years later that I learnt it was released in 1937. I found it scary as hell as a kid too.

People can expect what they want out of a relationship as long as it is honest and mutually accepted. There are many things that I expect from a relationship that go beyond monogamy. I require my partner to not take heroin. I require my partner to want to travel to different countries with me. You don't get randomly placed with a partner and then start demanding things from them. You find someone who wants the same things as you. I have every respect for someone who doesn't want to travel ever, but I don't want to be in a relationship with them. I have every respect for someone who doesn't want to be monogamous, but I don't want to be in a relationship with them. It's nothing to do with controlling your partner, it's about choosing a partner that shares your values.

WRITING.TITLE: First time to China (need some help please!)
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm going to China for the first time with my girlfriend next year. We have changed our itinerary around a lot and this is the plan we have currently:
Shanghai - March 24th Zhangjiajie - March 28th Fenghuang - March 31st Guilin - April 3rd Guangzhou - April 6th
Does this seem realistic for the timespan?
Guilin looks beautiful in the photos I've seen, but I read that it will be very rainy in April. Has anyone been there around that time of year? We can obviously deal with some rain, I just wondered if there was any reason that it might negatively impact the visit (visibility, mobility etc).
Is it generally quite easy to hire private cars from hotels in China? What sort of prices might they be? We would like to make a day trip to Qianyang from Fenghuang which would be about 2 hours drive each way. Is it realistic to do this in a private car?
Is there any general advice or comments that might help us with our trip regarding our first time to China and our itinerary. Any help would be really appreciated.

I always put pineapple and bacon in a burger or a chicken sandwich. Sometimes pineapple in a stir fry too. Delish.

You seem to think that life can only be positive if you can experience pleasure by doing nothing. Boredom might be the default option if you sit alone in a room all day, but that's why people don't sit alone in a room all day. People have jobs and friends and hobbies, that provide constant stimulus. Having to put effort into life to get something back out isn't inherantly a bad thing as you seem to imply. You describe it like it's all a big chore to avoid boredom. That is a mindset that you have chosen to indulge in and not one that is shared by everyone. Life can be very difficult and not everyone has the same opportunities for happiness, but most people can work towards happiness in their life. I am very with my job, relationships, hobbies, and having worked for them makes them more satisfying, not a chore.

"To me" is already implied in the statement. You don't need to state that something is your opinion every time you state an opinion.

Do you think that people using "that's gay" so casually has been beneficial to the gay community? If I was gay I really wouldn't like the use of it. It has come from disrespectful origins and now that it's caught on, people are trying to dissociate the word from those. I can't see that any good has come of it. How will doing the same for other words make any positive impact? It doesn't take away the hurt of someone who wants to use words hurtfully, becuase the intent is still there.
Generally looks pretty good to me, but have a look on it on iPad, some of the text and buttons are cut off on either side with no way to read it. Make sure it's compatible with mobile platforms.

Your argument seems to rely quite heavily on the idea that film can look more realistic than theatre and therefore it is easier for the audience to suspend their disbelief. I disagree that it is easier to suspend disbelief in film, and even if it is, I disagree that makes it superior to theatre.
When films are going for realism, it can be more distracting when something breaks that. For example there is a film called "let the right one in", (one of my favourite films) which is very naturalistically acted and shot, despite being about vampires, but I am always very distracted by a scene where the filmmakers have used CGI on the faces of some cats. Although as film further matures and technology improves, this issue may decrease, I still believe that the more realistic something tries to be, the easier it is for that realism to be broken.
With theatre, I am not distracted by those things as much, as i don't expect to see real blood, or real talking animals etc.
When I went to see the lion king musical (a long time ago now, forgive me if I forget the details), I remember being overwhelmed by the appearance of certain animals. The way the elephants were constructed and the way they moved. I was overwhelmed by the sheer artistry, creativity and beauty of it. It didn't look anything like a real elephant, nor did it need to, I never doubted it was an elephant. I realise that this is probably not the sort of theatre you had in mind with your argument but Ijust use it to illustrate my point. The argument also extends to non musical theatre.
Is photography a better medium than painting because it's more realistic? Theatre is more than just conveying a story, you can bask in the live spectacle of it. The creativity of it. The joy of seeing a one off performance that is just for you that night, that will never be repeated identically again. Seeing an actor give a emotive uninterrupted performance. These are things that can make theatre special.
I don't believe either medium is 'better'. They both have their own joys. It comes down to taste which one you enjoy more.

This may be true, I don't know, and I don't have an opinion on dog meat, but I was only really addressing the part where he implied that all meat is the same morally. I think that each type of animal should be taken as its own case. As long as the criteria that you use is consistent in your own decision making, then I don't think it is hypocritical.
Thanks! If you have any other music suggestions I'd love to hear them.

Taking a more general look at it, I do not believe it is hypocritical at all to criticise someone else's meat choice when you yourself eat meat. For example, I would be critical of a person or culture that farmed and ate Chimpanzees, but not chickens. This is because I believe that a chimpanzee has a higher level of self awareness and higher capacity for emotional distress than that of a chicken. For this reason, I do not believe that "meat is meat".
Similar arguments could be made for dogs (although I do not personally have an opinion on it). Regardless of where you draw the line at meat eating (and I think most of us do draw a line somewhere), I don't think it's hypocritical to do so.

Yeah, there's a whole compilation album of songs recorded in Saigon around 1968-1974 during the war, called "Saigon Rock and Soul", it's all great. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL833E925721802958

The English language is such a tangled mess of inconsistencies, irregularities, weird pronunciations, and other baffling features. It has been argued that you could spell the word "fish" as "ghoti".
"gh", pronounced [f] as in tough [tf];
"o", pronounced [] as in women [wmn]; and
"ti", pronounced [] as in nation [nen].
You can try and go through and sort out all these quirks, but doing so would create a drastically different language. There is no governing body over the English language. Language evolves naturally. Attempts to artificially dictate how people *should* use the language are generally ignored.
The English language as we know it, with its "C"s, "X"s and "Q"s won't disappear. I'm not going to start changing how I go about spelling words at this point in my life. At most you would create an alternative version of the language. If anything this will make learning the language more confusing, as you will have to learn two versions of the language. Consider how much existing material is already written in English with the letters that you wish to remove.

WRITING.TEXT: I think that would a pretty common response and one that I agree with, but I don't understand specifically what you mean by "there should be no sympathy". Especially when everyone takes those risks in their life. This hypothetical person just had bad luck with this specific risk.

But you said "there should be no sympathy for them". What does that mean? If I hear that one of my friends died in a diving accident, what do you think I should feel about that? Should I just think, "well a good person died doing what he loved, but it doesn't matter because he knew there was a slight risk involved so it's his own fault". It's a very strange way to view the world.

Life is never without risk. You take risks when you drive a car, drink alcohol, cross a road, go on holiday, climb a mountain, swim with sharks, eat unhealthy food. Everyone individually decides what risks are worth taking in their own lives and which ones are not. If you are not passionate about mountain climbing, then it's not a risk worth taking for you. I enjoy SCUBA diving occasionally. I am aware that there is risk of death. I do it responsibly and as safely as I can.
You can reduce the risk in your life massively by staying in your house, only eating healthy food, never making unnecessary journeys, never leaving your comfort zone. But I would say this runs a bigger risk, the risk of wasting your life.

Althought there certainly is plenty of nostalgia going on, I do disagree. Toy Story was one of my favourite films as a kid, and Toy Story 3 met and exceeded any expectations I could have had. It did to me as an adult what the first one did as a child, and more so. I think it's the best of the 3.
I agree it is more of a grey area when it comes down to personal safety.
I would suggest that women can make their own decisions about whether they want to work with dangerous chemicals. Edit: And men too, obviously.

What does it mean to favor men in the example of a job that needs strength. That a woman needs to perform to a higher standard than a man? Hiring more men than women in a manual job that requires a lot of strength isn't discrimination, because it is likely that more men are capable for the job, more men want the job and more men apply for the job. However, why would you discriminate in favour of men? Why shouldn't a woman be able to compete for a job by the same set of standards that a man is held?

You should not discriminate based on gender or colour. "if it's a strength based job favor the man for the job", no, favour the person who is better for the job, regardless of gender. There are plenty of women who are stronger and fitter than men. This is exactly why you should NOT discriminate. You could employ an inferior male worker instead of a superior female one.

WRITING.TITLE: Vietnamese man on the Mekong, Can Tho [3283x2188] [OC]

WRITING.TEXT:
I agree with you, but on the other hand, if the building was designed with a higher resale value in mind, it probably would have got fewer upvotes on reddit. The point was clearly to attract attention and turn heads, not guarantee a safe resell. I understand there are risks with that, but as someone looking at a picture on the Internet, I don't care about those.
I hope I don't sound aggressive, I respect your opinion, and as I said, I don't know the first thing about architecture other than what is pleasing to my eye. It's just that when I saw the picture it was exciting to see a building so different and made me want to see it in real life.

I agree that some of your points are valid, but "no subjectivity about it" seems silly to me when you're discussing whether anything is good or bad.
Presumably resale value wasn't a priority when you design a building like this. That's like saying a film isn't good because it won't sell to a big audience. What would happen if everyone made their house in the shape of their favourite thing is irrelevant because they don't.
Again I'm not saying that your points are not valid, but I am saying it's subjective. I don't think something can fairly be judged by rules that it is breaking intentionally.
I don't know a thing about architecture but it makes me sad that people don't like this. It looks beautiful to me and I haven't seen a building like it before.

Our basic instincts are set up by an evolutionary drive to survive and reproduce, however in many ways we have taken control of those instincts and we make life our own. For example, the goal of sex is reproduction, that is why it exists. However we have now invented contraception. We use sex to express love, to relieve stress, to have fun. It has nothing to do with its goal of reproduction if we are using contraception, although the goal of reproduction is what shaped our desires at a base level.
With art, maybe at a base level it might have been to demonstrate to potential mates intelligence or creativity, but now many people create art for the sheer love of it.
I am undecided as to whether I want children in the future, but as of right now, I don't want children. It doesn't mean my life has any less meaning. I have been shaped by my genes to survive and reproduce, but I have a mind advanced enough to take control of my life and make my own decisions.

WRITING.TITLE: Two young Buddhists sit upon a temple in Bagan, Myanmar [3400 x 5100] [OC]
Are there opportunities to freelance (photography/videography) while teaching English in HCMC?
WRITING.TEXT:
My girlfriend is looking into teaching English in Vietnam for a year or so. She wants me to go with her, and I very much want to. We've been to Vietnam twice and we absolutely love it. The thought of getting our TEFL qualifications and teaching out there for an extended period of time sounds so much fun (and also challenging).
Here in the UK I am trying to establish myself as a freelance videographer, doing weddings, corporate/business videos and music videos.
I am worried that moving to Vietnam would completely halt my progress of this.
What I was wondering was, are there opportunities to find work as a freelance videographer/photographer in somewhere like Ho Chi Minh City. I would price myself competitively and just use the money to supplement my teaching wage.
In an ideal world I would spend half of my time teaching English, and half shooting videos or photos for companies (and/or weddings). Is a pipe dream with no root in reality, or is this something that is possible? I have heard that there are many start ups in HCMC, which is why I thought it might not be entirely outside the realms of possibility. I would not be looking for big money from the video work, just to continue working and developing in the field.
Any advice or information relating to my situation would be very greatly appreciated. Thanks.
If a prisoner wants to be in prison, is he free? I can't understand why you would think this man is free.

I think if you are locked in a room against your will, you are not free regardless of whether you want to be there. If a prisoner wants to be be in prison, he isn't free because he doesn't have the CHOICE to leave. I would say that freedom is nothing to do with happiness, it is to do with the choice to do (or attempt to do without restriction from others) the things that you want.
